awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Northern Ohio AGEP-T: A Racially and Ethnically Inclusive Graduate Education Model in Biology, Chemistry and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Case Western Reserve University, Kent State University, the University of Akron, the University of Toledo, Youngstown State University, Bowling Green University and Cleveland State University will collaborate to create the Northern Ohio Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (NOA-AGEP): A Racially and Ethnically Inclusive Graduate Education Model in Biology, Chemistry and Engineering (BCE). These alliance schools will also partner with Central State University and Tuskegee University. This project was created in response to the NSF's Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program solicitation (NSF 14-505) for the AGEP-Transformation (AGEP-T) track. The AGEP-T track targets strategic alliances of institutions and organizations to develop, implement, and study innovative evidence-based models and standards for STEM graduate education, postdoctoral training, and academic STEM career preparation that eliminate or mitigate negative factors and promote positive practices for underrepresented minorities (URMs). The NOA-AGEP project will develop, implement, and study a model to improve URM student participation, preparation, and success in BCE graduate education, and to prepare them for entry into the professoriate

This AGEP-T project will uniquely contribute to foundational knowledge about the recruitment, retention and graduation of doctoral URMs in BCE. The emphasis on inclusive graduate education, an "umbrella" of supports for graduate students, and extensive diversity training for BCE faculty and staff offers an exceptional opportunity for a regional group of universities with low URM STEM doctoral student enrollment to investigate the promotion of inclusive policies, practices and initiatives.  The lessons learned as this project progresses, and the ultimate results from the work, will provide information that will be beneficial to educators, administrators and policymakers, as well as the general public.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Northern Ohio AGEP Alliance (NOA-AGEP) formed in 2014 to develop, implement, study, and institutionalize a model to improve underrepresented minority (URM) student participation, preparation, and success in STEM graduate education, and to prepare them for entry into the professoriate. NOA-AGEP is a consortium of seven STEM PhD-granting universities: Bowling Green State University (BGSU), Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), Cleveland State University (CSU), Kent State University (KSU), University of Akron (UA), University of Toledo (UT), and Youngstown State University (YSU). 

The Cohort

NOA-AGEP recruited 32 African American and Hispanic/Latine American AGEP Scholars who matriculated at an Alliance PhD program in biological sciences, chemistry, or engineering in 2016 and 2017 to form the AGEP Scholar cohort. At the conclusion of the NOA-AGEP NSF award, 17 AGEP scholars had completed their degrees and 11 plan to graduate by the end of the next academic year.

The Model

NOA-AGEP leveraged the unique campus communities across the Alliance to share current successes and challenges in supporting URM STEM doctoral students through graduate school and into the professoriate. This resulted in an Alliance model in two parts: Professional Development and Institutional Engagement. 

Professional Development

Bridge Weekend occurred over three days at the end of the summer in 2016 and 2017 to induct new scholars into the NOA-AGEP community, allow attendees to forge and expand connections with peers, faculty, and administrators, and become oriented to the NOA-AGEP mission, goals, values, and strategies.

Academic Coaching inspires, develops and supports AGEP Scholars for realizing their academic and career-life goals; recognizing and leveraging their unique strengths, characteristics and realities; and engaging in proactive, intentional development of academic, research and leadership competencies that lead to outstanding learning, performance and success. The coaching process explores their passion for STEM, expectations for the doctoral journey, and ideal self, including reflection on their core values, career-life aspirations, and personal vision. 

Mentor Circles provided a purposeful network of support to our AGEP Scholars. NOA-AGEP recruited mentors from various roles associated with an academic research career: faculty, postdoc, senior graduate student, university administration, and industry. 

Annual Research Symposia integrated URM STEM-specific programming within larger research conferences on Alliance campuses. In addition to traditional research conference participation, AGEP Scholars attended NOA-AGEP-specific keynote and breakout sessions to cover topics in support of that year's theme. These themes included Tools for Academic Conference Success (UT 2017), Roles of a STEM Scholar and Mentor (YSU 2018), Thriving in the STEM Professoriate (CWRU 2019), and Beyond the PhD (KSU, 2020; post-poned to 2021 due to COVID-19).

Institutional Engagement

Diversity 360 provided customized modules for a campus community to advance its efforts to be a welcoming, inclusive environment for learning, leading, and innovation. These modules engaged participants in learning to: increase capacity to recognize and engage in dialogue across the breadth of differences; deepen understanding of how affiliations in privileged and marginalized groups impact treatment on campus, campus climate and productivity; deepen awareness of types of microaggressions and how they affect experiences on campus and in the local community; and discover ways to become a change agent and diversity champion with new knowledge, ideas and resources about university policies, programs and best practices. 

Diversity Scorecard examined the AGEP Scholar experience related to the non-AGEP graduate student experience via a survey on each Alliance campus. Students self-reported all data across five question blocks related to: Demographics, Milestones Reached, Professional Development, Program Experience/Climate, and Campus Climate.

Dissemination

Results from the NOA-AGEP project have been disseminated via two dissertations from doctoral students on the NOA-AGEP Research Team and at numerous conferences. A selected list of citations appears below.

Hopson, R., Hall, J., Horsford, S., Rozek, C., Smith, M. R., Howard, A., Mobley, M. S., Munro-Stasiuk, M., & Jackson, S. (November 2018). How Evaluation Speaks Truth to Power in STEM Persistence and Support: Lessons Learned from the Northern Ohio AGEP Alliance. American Evaluation Association Annual Meeting. Cleveland, OH.

Jaks, Q. (2021). What?s good in da hood? Hoodology in organizations [Doctoral dissertation, Case Western Reserve University]. OhioLink Electronic Theses and Dissertations Center. 

Linkous, C. (2021). Quest 2018: Wearing mentoring and mentee shoes at the same time. [Poster]. AGEP National Research Conference, Virtual Meeting.

Rozek, C., & Barbour, S. (2017). Empowering 1st Generation and Underrepresented Students to Navigate Graduate School. [Conference session]. Council of Graduate Schools Annual Meeting. Scottsdale, AZ.

Smith, M., Howard, A., and Nickel-Schindewolf, S. (2017). NOA-AGEP Academic Coaching. [Poster}. Promising Practices in Supporting Graduate and Professional Students Conference. St. Louis, MO.

Sugiyama, K. (2019). Taking Inclusion Home: Crossing Boundaries and Negotiating Tensions to Become an Includer [Doctoral dissertation, Case Western Reserve University]. OhioLINK Electronic Theses and Dissertations Center. 

Sugiyama, K, Jaks, Q. & Bilimoria, D. (August 2019). Becoming a minority scientist: (De)racialized professional identity construction. [Paper] 79th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management. Boston, MA.
